statements.name: PROC DATASETS
statements.description: Manages SAS files.

arguments.name: ALTER=
arguments.description: provides Alter access to any alter-protected SAS file in the SAS library.

arguments.name: DETAILS
arguments.description: includes information in the log about the number of observations, number of variables, number of indexes, and data set labels.

arguments.name: NODETAILS
arguments.description: includes information in the log about the number of observations, number of variables, number of indexes, and data set labels.

arguments.name: ENCRYPTKEY=
arguments.description: specifies the key value for AES encryption.

arguments.name: FORCE
arguments.description: forces either a RUN group to execute even when there are errors or forces an Append operation.

arguments.name: GENNUM=
arguments.description: restricts processing for generation data sets.

arguments.name: KILL
arguments.description: deletes SAS files.

arguments.name: LIBRARY=
arguments.description: specifies the procedure input/output library.

arguments.name: MEMTYPE=
arguments.description: restricts processing to a certain type of SAS file.

arguments.name: NOLIST
arguments.description: suppresses the printing of the directory.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: suppresses the printing of the output to the log and listing.

arguments.name: NOWARN
arguments.description: suppresses error processing.

arguments.name: PW=
arguments.description: provides Read, Write, or Alter access.

arguments.name: READ=
arguments.description: provides Read access.

statements.name: AGE
statements.description: Renames a group of related SAS files in a library.

arguments.name: current-name
arguments.description: is a SAS file that the procedure renames. current-name receives the name of the first name in related-SAS-file(s).

arguments.name: related-SAS-file
arguments.description: is one or more SAS files in the SAS library.

arguments.name: ALTER=
arguments.description: provides the Alter password for any alter-protected SAS files named in the AGE statement. Because an AGE statement renames and deletes SAS files, you need Alter access to use the AGE statement. You can use the option either in parentheses after the name of each SAS file or after a forward slash.

arguments.name: MEMTYPE=
arguments.description: restricts processing to one member type. All of the SAS files that you name in the AGE statement must be the same member type. You can use the option after a forward slash after the name of each SAS file.

statements.name: APPEND
statements.description: Adds the observations from one SAS data set to the end of another SAS data set.

arguments.name: BASE=
arguments.description: names the data set to which you want to add observations.

arguments.name: libref
arguments.description: specifies the library that contains the SAS data set. If you omit the libref, the default is the libref for the procedure input library. If you are using PROC APPEND, the default for libref is either Work or User.

arguments.name: SAS-data-set
arguments.description: names a SAS data set. If the APPEND statement cannot find an existing data set with this name, it creates a new data set in the library. That is, you can use the APPEND statement to create a data set by specifying a new data set name in the BASE= argument.

arguments.name: APPENDVER=
arguments.description: uses the Version 6 behavior for appending observations to the BASE= data set.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: names the SAS data set containing observations that you want to append to the end of the SAS data set specified in the BASE= argument.

arguments.name: libref
arguments.description: specifies the library that contains the SAS data set. If you omit libref, the default is the libref for the procedure input library. The DATA= data set can be from any SAS library. You must use the two-level name if the data set resides in a library other than the procedure input library.

arguments.name: SAS-data-set
arguments.description: names a SAS data set. If the APPEND statement cannot find an existing data set with this name, it stops processing.

arguments.name: ENCRYPTKEY=
arguments.description: specifies the key value for AES encryption.

arguments.name: FORCE
arguments.description: forces the APPEND statement to concatenate data sets.

arguments.name: GETSORT
arguments.description: copies the sort indicator from the DATA= data set to the BASE= data set.

arguments.name: NOWARN
arguments.description: suppresses the warning when used with the FORCE option.

statements.name: ATTRIB
statements.description: Associates a format, informat, or label with variables in the SAS data set specified in the MODIFY statement.

arguments.name: variable-list
arguments.description: names the variables that you want to associate with the attributes. You can list the variables in any form that SAS allows.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: associates a format with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: INFORMAT=
arguments.description: associates an informat with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: associates a label with variables in the variable-list.

statements.name: AUDIT
statements.description: Initiates and controls event logging to an audit file as well as suspends, resumes, or terminates event logging in an audit file.

arguments.name: SAS-file
arguments.description: specifies the SAS data file in the procedure input library that you want to audit.

arguments.name: SAS-password
arguments.description: specifies the password for the SAS data file.

arguments.name: ENCRYPTKEY=
arguments.description: specifies the key value for AES encryption.

arguments.name: GENNUM=
arguments.description: specifies that the SUSPEND, RESUME, or TERMINATE action be performed on the audit trail of a generation file.

statements.name: CHANGE
statements.description: Renames one or more SAS files in the same SAS library.

arguments.name: old-name=
arguments.description: changes the name of a SAS file in the input data library. old-name must be the name of an existing SAS file in the input data library.

arguments.name: ENCRYPTKEY=
arguments.description: specifies the key value for AES encryption.

arguments.name: ALTER=
arguments.description: provides the Alter password.

arguments.name: GENNUM=
arguments.description: restricts processing for generation data sets.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: refers to the base version and all historical versions of a generation group.
refers to the base version and all historical versions of a generation group.

arguments.name: integer
arguments.description: refers to a specific version from a generation group. Specifying a positive number is an absolute reference to a specific generation number that is appended to a data set's name (that is, gennum=2 specifies MYDATA#002). Specifying a negative number is a relative reference to a historical version in relation to the base version, from the youngest to the oldest (that is, gennum=-1 refers to the youngest historical version).

arguments.name: MEMTYPE=
arguments.description: restricts processing to one member type.

statements.name: CONTENTS
statements.description: Describes the contents of one or more SAS data sets and prints the directory of the SAS library.

arguments.name: CENTILES
arguments.description: prints centiles information for indexed variables.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: specifies the input data set.

arguments.name: <libref.>SAS-data-set
arguments.description: names one SAS data set to process. The default for libref is the libref of the procedure input library. For example, to obtain the contents of the SAS data set HtWt from the procedure input library, use the following CONTENTS statement:

arguments.name: <>_ALL_
arguments.description:
gives you information about all SAS data sets that have the type or types specified by the MEMTYPE= option. libref refers to the SAS library. The default for libref is the libref of the procedure input library.
• If you are using the _ALL_ keyword, you need Read access to all read-protected SAS data sets in the SAS library.
• DATA=_ALL_ automatically prints a listing of the SAS files that are contained in the SAS library. Note that for SAS views, all librefs that are associated with the views must be assigned in the current session in order for them to be processed for the listing.

arguments.name: DETAILS
arguments.description: includes information in the output about the number of observations, number of variables, number of indexes, and data set labels.

arguments.name: NODETAILS
arguments.description: includes information in the output about the number of observations, number of variables, number of indexes, and data set labels.

arguments.name: DIRECTORY
arguments.description: prints a list of the SAS files in the SAS library.

arguments.name: ENCRYPTKEY=
arguments.description: specifies the key value for AES encryption.

arguments.name: FMTLEN
arguments.description: prints the length of a variable's informat or format.

arguments.name: MEMTYPE=
arguments.description: restricts processing to one or more types of SAS files.

arguments.name: NODS
arguments.description: suppresses the printing of individual files.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: suppresses the printing of the output.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: prints a list of variables in a specified order.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the name for an output data set.

arguments.name: OUT2=
arguments.description: specifies the name of an output data set to contain information about indexes and integrity constraints.

arguments.name: SHORT
arguments.description: prints abbreviated output.

arguments.name: VARNUM
arguments.description: print a list of the variables by their position in the data set. By default, the CONTENTS statement lists the variables alphabetically.

statements.name: COPY
statements.description: Copies all or some of the SAS files in a SAS library.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: names the SAS library to copy SAS files to.

arguments.name: ACCEL
arguments.description: specifies to perform the copy operation in CAS. Both the IN= and OUT= libraries must be CAS engine libraries and they must use the same CAS session.

arguments.name: NOACCEL
arguments.description: specifies to perform the copy operation in the SAS Compute Server. Both the IN= and OUT= libraries must be CAS engine libraries and they must use the same CAS session.

arguments.name: CLONE
arguments.description: specifies whether to copy data set attributes.

arguments.name: CONSTRAINT=
arguments.description: specifies whether to copy all integrity constraints when copying a data set.

arguments.name: DATECOPY
arguments.description: copies the SAS internal date and time at which the SAS file was created and the date and time at which it was last modified to the resulting copy of the file.

arguments.name: ENCRYPTKEY=
arguments.description: specifies the key value needed to copy data sets in the IN= library that have AES encryption.

arguments.name: FORCE
arguments.description: enables you to use the MOVE option for a SAS data set on which an audit trail exists.

arguments.name: IN=
arguments.description: names the SAS library containing SAS files to copy.

arguments.name: INDEX=
arguments.description: specifies whether to copy all indexes for a data set

arguments.name: MEMTYPE=
arguments.description: restricts processing to one or more member types.

arguments.name: MOVE
arguments.description: moves SAS files from the input data library to the output data library.

arguments.name: ALTER=
arguments.description: provides the Alter password for any alter-protected SAS files that you are moving from one data library to another. Because the MOVE option deletes the SAS file from the original data library, you need Alter access to move the SAS file.

arguments.name: OVERRIDE=
arguments.description: overrides specified output data set options copied from the input data set.

arguments.name: NOCLONE
arguments.description: See the description of .

statements.name: DELETE
statements.description: Deletes SAS files from a SAS library.

arguments.name: SAS-file
arguments.description: specifies one or more SAS files that you want to delete. If the SAS file has an ALTER= password assigned, it must be specified in order to delete the SAS file. You can also use a numbered range list or colon list. For more information, see .

arguments.name: ALTER=
arguments.description: provides the Alter password.

arguments.name: ENCRYPTKEY=
arguments.description: specifies the key value for AES encryption.

arguments.name: GENNUM=
arguments.description: restricts processing for generation data sets.

arguments.name: MEMTYPE=
arguments.description: restricts processing to one member type

statements.name: EXCHANGE
statements.description: Exchanges the names of two SAS files in a SAS library.

arguments.name: name=
arguments.description: exchanges the names of SAS files in the procedure input library. Both name and other-name must already exist in the procedure input library.

arguments.name: ALTER=
arguments.description: provides the Alter password for any alter-protected SAS files whose names you want to exchange. You can use the option either in parentheses after the name of each SAS file or after a forward slash.

arguments.name: MEMTYPE=
arguments.description: restricts processing to one member type. You can exchange only the names of SAS files of the same type. You can use the option either in parentheses after the name of each SAS file or after a forward slash.

statements.name: EXCLUDE
statements.description: Excludes SAS files from copying.

arguments.name: SAS-file
arguments.description: specifies one or more SAS files to exclude from the copy operation. All SAS files you name in the EXCLUDE statement must be in the library that is specified in the IN= option in the COPY statement. If the SAS files are generation groups, the EXCLUDE statement allows only selection of the base versions.

arguments.name: MEMTYPE=
arguments.description: restricts processing to one member type. You can use the option either in parentheses after the name of each SAS file or after a forward slash.

statements.name: FORMAT
statements.description: Assigns, changes, and removes variable formats in the SAS data set specified in the MODIFY statement permanently.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies one or more variables whose format you want to assign, change, or remove. If you want to disassociate a format with a variable, list the variable last in the list with no format following:

arguments.name: format
arguments.description: specifies a format to apply to the variable or variables listed before it. If you do not specify a format, the FORMAT statement removes any format associated with the variables in variable-list.

statements.name: IC CREATE
statements.description: Creates an integrity constraint.

arguments.name: constraint
arguments.description: is the type of constraint. Here is a list of valid values:

arguments.name: constraint-name
arguments.description: is an optional name for the constraint.

arguments.name: MESSAGE=
arguments.description: message-string is the text of an error message to be written to the log when the data fails the constraint:

arguments.name: MSGTYPE=
arguments.description: controls the format of the integrity constraint error message. By default when the MESSAGE= option is specified, the message that you define is inserted into the SAS error message for the constraint, separated by a space. MSGTYPE=USER suppresses the SAS portion of the message.

statements.name: IC DELETE
statements.description: Deletes an integrity constraint.

arguments.name: constraint-name
arguments.description: names one or more constraints to delete. For example, to delete the constraints Unique_D and Unique_E, use the following statement: ic delete Unique_D Unique_E;

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: deletes all constraints for the SAS data file specified in the preceding MODIFY statement.

statements.name: IC REACTIVATE
statements.description: Reactivates a foreign key integrity constraint that is inactive.

arguments.name: foreign-key-name
arguments.description: is the name of the foreign key to reactivate.

arguments.name: libref
arguments.description: refers to the SAS library containing the data set that contains the primary key that is referenced by the foreign key.

statements.name: INDEX CENTILES
statements.description: Updates centiles statistics for indexed variables.

arguments.name: index
arguments.description: names one or more indexes.

arguments.name: REFRESH
arguments.description: updates centiles immediately, regardless of the value of UPDATECENTILES.

arguments.name: UPDATECENTILES=
arguments.description: specifies when centiles are to be updated. It is not practical to update centiles after every data set update. Therefore, you can specify as the value of UPDATECENTILES the percentage of the data values that can be changed before centiles for the indexed variables are updated.

statements.name: INDEX CREATE
statements.description: Creates simple or composite indexes for the SAS data set specified in the MODIFY statement.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: creates a simple index on the specified variable.

arguments.name: index=
arguments.description: creates a composite index. The name that you specify for index is the name of the composite index. It must be a valid SAS name and cannot be the same as any variable name or any other composite index name. You must specify at least two variables.

arguments.name: NOMISS
arguments.description: excludes from the index all observations with missing values for all index variables.

arguments.name: UNIQUE
arguments.description: specifies that the combination of values of the index variables must be unique.

arguments.name: UPDATECENTILES=
arguments.description: specifies when centiles are to be updated.

statements.name: INDEX DELETE
statements.description: Deletes one or more indexes associated with the SAS data set specified in the MODIFY statement.

arguments.name: index
arguments.description: names one or more indexes to delete. The index(es) must be for variables in the SAS data set that is named in the preceding MODIFY statement. You can delete both simple and composite indexes.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: deletes all indexes, except for indexes that are owned by an integrity constraint. When an index is created, it is marked as owned by the user, by an integrity constraint, or by both. If an index is owned by both a user and an integrity constraint, the index is not deleted until both an IC DELETE statement and an INDEX DELETE statement are processed.

statements.name: INFORMAT
statements.description: Assigns, changes, and removes variable informats in the data set specified in the MODIFY statement permanently.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies one or more variables whose informats you want to assign, change, or remove. If you want to disassociate an informat with a variable, list the variable last in the list with no informat following:

arguments.name: informat
arguments.description: specifies an informat for the variables immediately preceding it in the statement. If you do not specify an informat, the INFORMAT statement removes any existing informats for the variables in variable-list.

statements.name: INITIATE
statements.description: Creates an audit file that has the same name as the SAS data file and a data set type of AUDIT.

arguments.name: AUDIT_ALL=
arguments.description: specifies whether logging can be suspended and audit settings can be changed. AUDIT_ALL=YES specifies that all images are logged and cannot be suspended. That is, you cannot use the LOG statement to turn off logging of particular images, and you cannot suspend event logging by using the SUSPEND statement. To turn off logging, you must use the TERMINATE statement, which terminates event logging and deletes the audit file.

statements.name: LABEL
statements.description: Assigns, changes, and removes variable labels for the SAS data set specified in the MODIFY statement.

arguments.name: variable=
arguments.description: specifies a text string of up to 256 characters. If the label text contains single quotation marks, use double quotation marks around the label, or use two single quotation marks in the label text and enclose the string in single quotation marks. To remove a label from a data set, assign a label that is equal to a blank that is enclosed in quotation marks.

statements.name: LOG
statements.description: specifies the audit file settings.

arguments.name: ADMIN_IMAGE=
arguments.description: specifies whether the administrative events are logged to the audit file (that is, the SUSPEND and RESUME actions).

arguments.name: BEFORE_IMAGE=
arguments.description: specifies whether the before-update record images are logged to the audit file.

arguments.name: DATA_IMAGE=
arguments.description: specifies whether the added, deleted, and after-update record images are logged to the audit file.

arguments.name: ERROR_IMAGE=
arguments.description: specifies whether the after-update record images are logged to the audit file.

statements.name: MODIFY
statements.description: Changes the attributes of a SAS file and, through the use of subordinate statements, the attributes of variables in the SAS file.

arguments.name: SAS-file
arguments.description: specifies a SAS file that exists in the procedure input library.

arguments.name: ALTER=
arguments.description: modifies an Alter password.

arguments.name: CORRECTENCODING=
arguments.description: changes the character-set encoding.

arguments.name: ENCRYPTKEY=
arguments.description: specifies a key value for AES encryption.

arguments.name: DTC=
arguments.description: specifies a creation date and time.

arguments.name: GENMAX=
arguments.description: modifies the maximum number of versions for a generation group.

arguments.name: GENNUM=
arguments.description: modifies a historical version.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: assigns or change a data set label.

arguments.name: MEMTYPE=
arguments.description: restricts processing to a certain type of SAS file.

arguments.name: PW=
arguments.description: modifies a Read, Write, or Alter password.

arguments.name: READ=
arguments.description: modifies a Read password.

arguments.name: SORTEDBY=
arguments.description: specifies how the data are currently sorted.

arguments.name: TYPE=
arguments.description: assigns or changes a special data set type.

arguments.name: WRITE=
arguments.description: modifies a Write password.

statements.name: QUIT
statements.description: Executes any statements that have not executed and ends the procedure.

statements.name: REBUILD
statements.description: Specifies whether to restore or delete the disabled indexes and integrity constraints.

arguments.name: SAS-file
arguments.description: specifies a SAS data file that contains the disabled indexes and integrity constraints. You can also use a numbered range list or colon list.

arguments.name: ENCRYPTKEY=
arguments.description: specifies a key value for AES encryption.

arguments.name: ALTER=
arguments.description: provides the Alter password.

arguments.name: GENNUM=
arguments.description: restricts processing for generation data sets.

arguments.name: MEMTYPE=
arguments.description: restricts processing to one member type.

arguments.name: NOINDEX
arguments.description: specifies to delete the disabled indexes and integrity constraints.

statements.name: RENAME
statements.description: Renames variables in the SAS data set specified in the MODIFY statement.

arguments.name: old-name=
arguments.description: changes the name of a variable in the data set specified in the MODIFY statement. old-name must be a variable that already exists in the data set. new-name cannot be the name of a variable that already exists in the data set or the name of an index, and the new name must be a valid SAS name.

statements.name: REPAIR
statements.description: Attempts to restore damaged SAS data sets or catalogs, in permanent libraries, to a usable condition.

arguments.name: SAS-file
arguments.description: specifies one or more SAS data sets or catalogs in the procedure input library. You can also use a numbered range list or colon list.

arguments.name: ALTER=
arguments.description: provides the Alter password.

arguments.name: ENCRYPTKEY=
arguments.description: specifies a key value for AES encryption.

arguments.name: GENNUM=
arguments.description: restricts processing for generation data sets.

arguments.name: MEMTYPE=
arguments.description: restricts processing to one member type.

statements.name: RESUME
statements.description: resumes event logging to the audit file, if it was suspended.

statements.name: SAVE
statements.description: Deletes all the SAS files in a library except the ones listed in the SAVE statement.

arguments.name: SAS-file
arguments.description: specifies one or more SAS files that you do not want to delete from the SAS library.

arguments.name: MEMTYPE=
arguments.description: restricts processing to one member type. You can use the option either in parentheses after the name of each SAS file or after a forward slash.

statements.name: SELECT
statements.description: Selects SAS files for copying.

arguments.name: SAS-file
arguments.description: specifies one or more SAS files that you want to copy. All of the SAS files that you name must be in the data library that is referenced by the libref named in the IN= option in the COPY statement. If the SAS files have generation groups, all the generations are copied because the SELECT statement does not allow you to select specific versions.

arguments.name: ALTER=
arguments.description: provides the Alter password for any alter-protected SAS files that you are moving from one data library to another. Because you are moving and thus deleting a SAS file from a SAS library, you need Alter access. You can use the option either in parentheses after the name of each SAS file or after a forward slash.

arguments.name: ENCRYPTKEY=
arguments.description: specifies the key value for AES encryption.

arguments.name: MEMTYPE=
arguments.description: restricts processing to one member type. You can use the option either in parentheses after the name of each SAS file or after a forward slash.

statements.name: SUSPEND
statements.description: suspends event logging to the audit file, but does not delete the audit file.

statements.name: TERMINATE
statements.description: terminates event logging and deletes the audit file.

statements.name: USER_VAR
statements.description: defines optional variables to be logged in the audit file with each update to an observation. When you use USER_VAR, it must follow an INITIATE statement.

arguments.name: variable-name
arguments.description: is a name for the variable.
indicates that the variable is a character variable.

arguments.name: length
arguments.description: specifies the length of the variable.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a label for the variable.

statements.name: XATTR ADD
statements.description: Adds an extended attribute to a variable or a data set.
statements.help:
XATTR ADD DS  attribute-name-1=attribute-value-1 
	<attribute-name-2=attribute-value-2 ...>;
or
XATTR ADD VAR  variable-name-1  (attribute-name-1=attribute-value-1
	< attribute-name-2=attribute-value-2 ...>) 
	<variable-name-2 (attribute-name-1=attribute-value-1 
	<attribute-name-2=attribute-value-2 ...>) >;

arguments.name: DS
arguments.description: adds an extended attribute to a data set. If the extended attribute already exists, an error will be returned.

arguments.name: VAR
arguments.description: adds an extended attribute to a variable. If the extended attribute already exists, an error will be returned.

statements.name: XATTR DELETE
statements.description: Deletes all extended attributes from a SAS file.

arguments.name: DELETE
arguments.description: deletes all extended attributes from a data set.

statements.name: XATTR OPTIONS
statements.description: Specifies options as needed for extended attributes. Currently, only SEGLEN= is a valid option.

arguments.name: SEGLEN=
arguments.description: Indicates the length of the storage element that will hold the character extended attribute value. The value can be 1 to 32,760 bytes.

statements.name: XATTR REMOVE
statements.description: Removes an extended attribute from a variable or a data set.

arguments.name: DS
arguments.description: removes an extended attribute from a data set.

arguments.name: VAR
arguments.description: removes an extended attribute from a variable.

statements.name: XATTR SET
statements.description: Updates or adds extended attributes to variables or data sets.
statements.help:
XATTR SET DS  attribute-name-1=attribute-value-1 
	<attribute-name-2="attribute-value-2" ...>;
or
XATTR SET VAR  variable-name-1  (attribute-name-1=attribute-value-1 
	<attribute-name-2=attribute-value-2 ...>)
	<variable-name-2  (attribute-name-1=attribute-value-1 
	<attribute-name-2=attribute-value-2>  ...)>;

arguments.name: DS
arguments.description: updates or adds an extended attribute to a data set. If the data set extended attribute does not exist, it will be added. If it does exist, it will be updated with the value specified.

arguments.name: VAR
arguments.description: updates or adds an extended attribute to a variable. If the variable and extended attribute combination does not exist, the extended attribute will be added. If it does exist, the extended attribute will be updated with the one specified.

statements.name: XATTR UPDATE
statements.description: Updates an extended attribute to a variable or a data set.
statements.help:
XATTR UPDATE DS  attribute-name-1=attribute-value-1 
	<attribute-name-2=attribute-value-2 ...>;
or
XATTR UPDATE VAR  variable-name-1  (attribute-name-1=attribute-value-1 
	<attribute-name-2=attribute-value-2  ...>)
	<variable-name-2  (attribute-name-1=attribute-value-1 
	<attribute-name-2=attribute-value-2 ...>)>;

arguments.name: DS
arguments.description: updates an extended attribute in a data set. If the extended attribute does not exist, an error is written to the SAS log.

arguments.name: VAR
arguments.description: updates an extended attribute for a variable. If the variable and extended attribute combination is not found, an error message is written to the SAS log.
